185863956.review:
[h1] Rating: 5/5 [/h1]

Getting Over It is an artistic piece of gaming that offers the unique experience of climbing a mountain of piled up static objects. The key challenge of the game is that at any point the player can fall back to the beginning. Safety is not assured, and while Bennett Foddy grants a few safe areas, he takes them away quickly as well. 

Being apathetic to whether the player succeeds, the game only prioritizes being an effective abstraction. The best example of this is the control system, which requires the player to master an awkward task-specific representation of moving around a hammer. The more intuitive wild swings introduce the risk of accidents that send the player back to the beginning, while surgical precision can often prevent the player from building momentum.

While it isn't the most impressive game graphically or programmatically, Getting Over It offers a rare type of challenge that seemed worth completing for me.

If you play this game without breaks, you will get increasingly frustrated and make more mistakes which will make your more flustered and it'll continue in a loop until you eventually beat the game. 185623231.review:
This will be the only review that I've posted leaving a "Do not recommend" rating. But first, some backstory...

I received this game on Christmas (no this was not on my wishlist) from an irl friend. I've seen this game played by many streamers/youtubers so I decided to give it a shot... Should've just rejected it. However, I'm very stupid and I accepted the challenge.

Moving "Pot-guy" (stand in name for the player character) is an absolute pain to move around the environment with. Not only do you have to endure that you have to endure Mr. Foddy spouting some rando philosophy about life or some other stupid garbage that I couldn't care less about. I HIGHLY, recommend turning the voice-over volume down/off in the options menu. Additionally, he'll say something/a sad song will play when you fall a certain distance (yippee). I don't have a lot to say about the map itself only that it's a cluster of random props jammed together so if your into that you'll probably still hate this game.

I can't stand this game and strongly urge players to seek other forms of challenge (Celeste, Dark Souls Games, anything but this, etc.) but if you still want to play and beat this game here's what I did to preserve my sanity. Only play the game in small increments of time (talkin' like 15 minutes). Once you lose enough progress just exit out of the game and play it again the next day for the same amount of time. This prevents you from getting tilted which will help you in the long run.

Words really cannot describe how much I can't stand this game. Only thing that comes close is the AM speech from I have no mouth and I must scream.

TL; DR

I hate this game don't play it. If you do play it, play it in small increments of time

185507711.review:
Here's a simple recipe for delicious chocolate muffins:

Ingredients:
1 3/4 cups (220g) all-purpose flour
1/2 cup (50g) cocoa powder
1 cup (200g) sugar
1 1/2 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp salt
2 large eggs
1 cup (240ml) milk
1/2 cup (120ml) vegetable oil
1 tsp vanilla extract
1 cup (175g) chocolate chips (optional)
Instructions:
Preheat the Oven: Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C) and line a muffin tin with paper liners or grease it lightly.

Mix Dry Ingredients: In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

Mix Wet Ingredients: In another bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, vegetable oil, and vanilla extract.

Combine Wet and Dry Ingredients: Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients, stirring gently until just combined. Be careful not to overmix. If you're adding chocolate chips, fold them in at this stage.

Fill the Muffin Tin: Divide the batter evenly among the muffin cups, filling each about 2/3 full.

Bake: Bake for 18-22 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.

Cool and Serve: Let the muffins cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then transfer them to a wire rack to cool completely. Enjoy!

These muffins are moist and full of rich chocolate flavor. Feel free to add nuts, extra chocolate chunks, or even a swirl of peanut butter for variation!

185385862.review: This game puzzles me. It puzzles me because I do not feel anger when I play it. Not once in my experience with this game have I ever felt like destroying something because I failed to accomplish something. I think it is because I have grown up watching streamers and Youtubers play this game, and feel immense anger. I've seen Markiplier throw his mouse at his wall, and this thought has never crossed my mind. On my first playthrough of this game, I was stuck at the orange part, after the furniture. I tried and I tried my hardest to climb those rocks and kept failing, but not once did I feel hatred towards the games developer. It was only when I reached the end that I truly felt "anger", not because the ending section was hard, but because I had been told in every conversation and review relating to this game, it had been described as infuriating and rage inducing. And yet I felt nothing. As of the time when I am writing this review, I have completed this game 20 times. And every time I come back to it, I feel as if I am a blind man staring at Michelangelo's David, unable to see its beauty and magnificence. Because this game is art, all games are art, but some games are modern art, just throwing things around with no rhyme or reason with people saying there's a meaning, or that the beauty is that there is no meaning. This is not one of those games, it is more akin to the works of Picasso, in that it's meaning is more abstract than anything. And yet whenever I play it and feel nothing, I do feel that I am spitting on his work. As I write this, I am reminded of something Bennet Foddy says when you reach the chimney, where he describes the process of creating this game, and says that his inability to surpass the obstacles he has made is his fault as a player, rather than a developer. I feel similar in that respect, because everyone else seems to feel intense anger and rage when playing this, and yet I do not. My inability to feel anger while playing this game is not his fault, as the developer, but mine, as the player. It is my fault. I am blind, while everyone else can see. This game is truly a work of art, but it is one I cannot truly appreciate, and in this respect I feel remorse, remorse that I will never be able to see this game as so many others have, as Bennet has intended for me to see it. Perhaps I shall one day understand why, but for now, I remain unenlightened.

185143131.review:
I think Foddian games are poorly designed.
This is not to say "the game sucks because it's too hard", I love challenging games and actively seek out extra challenges in my favorites, but I just hate Foddian games.

But I know everyone who complains/criticizes about games like this is always flooded with "skill issue lmao get good", so I feel like I need to defend myself here.
I've gotten every achievement in games like Celeste, Cuphead, even Pizza Tower's P Ranks, but there's one very important difference between game these and Foddian games.
These games are actually trying to be fun.

Most games try to make the controls feel as good as possible, even sometimes weighing them in the player's favor with mechanics like coyote time, but part of the Foddian genre is to make the controls deliberately difficult so the game is artificially harder. Another part is to make mistakes frequently send you back a long distance. [b]Both of the genre defining traits are to make the game frustrating.[/b]

I think losing progress in particular is why it's so unfun for me. I don't like having to do everything I already know I can do all over again because I messed something up after it. You could say "you play roguelikes, isn't that the same thing?" but that's different because in roguelikes it's different from run to run. Sometimes the enemies are different, or I have different weapons and items, it's never the exact same run twice, but Foddian games are the exact same every time, and it's just wasting my time to make me climb for 30 minutes just to get back to the actually hard part.

Genuinely, I think the only reason games like this succeed is because people see youtubers and streamers playing it and struggling and go "I can do better than this fool" and then only stick with it to the end so they have the right to talk down on people who haven't beaten it.
Even so, I think it isn't usually impressive to beat a Foddian game. Foddian games are built to have no amount of skill overlap, so even if you've climbed Foddy's mountain 100 times it does nothing to prove if you are good at literally anything else. The only thing beating a Foddian proves is that you're persistent, but I don't know if it's out of the indomitable human spirit or wanting to not be called a loser, and only one of those is impressive.

To put it simply, Foddian games are deliberately designed to be unfun, frustrating, and only have value in watching mr. streamer yell at the top of their lungs so you can make fun of them, which is not a good silver lining to have.

185025516.review:
I got this game on sale for like 2 bucks. After booting it up the first time, I was filled with horror as the movement was very unusual to me. Later I started to get the game more. I got over a few obstaclese before turning the game off. Next time loading in I felt a bit more powerful. I got to the vertical wall, which I thought would be the biggest challenge of the journey. After some slip ups and a few comments from the narrator, I eventually got over the vertical wall. The slide area was the one where I spent most of my playtime in. Either it was trying to skip the slide completely or by making the jump from the grill to the other side... It took me a while to be able to consistently get to the staircase/camera area. As I progressed further to the "orange hell" zone, I felt more challenged. Obstacles were less forgiving. Every single slip up could mean going back to the slide area. Not to mention, that I fell all the way to the start a few times prior. As I got through the orange hell, my journey got a little bit comfier. I didn't risk losing so much progress by now. That's when a new enemy showed up... The anvil jump. I thought I was unstoppable, but I was wrong. The anvil jump drained me. Sometimes even sending me down to the hat jump. It took hours of practice to be able to get through it consistently. Had some trouble with the snowball jumps aswell. I even managed to get through the bucket jump with ease. The ice mountain was a challenge. The first time I ever got to it ended up in me falling all the way to the slide area via the cliff edge under the snake. I needed to rest. 
When I got on the game again, I was there once again - the slide area. I didn't struggle with it as much as I used to, eventually getting back to the snow area. I failed the anvil a few times, but eventually got back to the ice cliff. The final push. I was one with the hammer. I swung it like a windmill, until eventually... I got to the tower. The last obstacle in my way. I was scared of getting stucked on it and getting the bad ending or falling down the ice cliff again. But after some intense swings and jumps, I got over it.

184958377.review:
Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy is not just a game—it’s a test of patience, resilience, and the raw human spirit. From the moment you start, the game's minimalist design draws you into its world of frustration and triumph. Controlling a man in a cauldron with only a hammer might sound absurd, but it’s this absurdity that makes the exsperince so unique.

The physics-based gameplay is deceptively simple, yet the challenge lies in mastering the awkward mechanics. Each painstaking climb feels like a personal victory, while each fall serves as a reminder of the fragility of progress. The accompanying philosophical musings from Bennett Foddy add depth, turning moments of rage into reflections on failure and perseverance.

Despite its difficulty, the game rewards you with a sense of accomplishment that few other games offer. It’s not just about reaching the top; it’s about the emotional journey and learning to accept setbacks as part of the process. Getting Over It is a raw, unforgettable exsperince that challenges your mind and emotions in ways you never thought a game could.

If you're looking for something that tests your limits and offers a profound sense of growth, this game is a must-play. Just be ready to laugh, cry, and question your sanity—all in one wild exsperince.

184826564.review:
Getting Over It - це не легка гра, це незручна, дратуюча гра що зможе тобі добре вдарити по нервах.
Ти граєш за мужика, ноги якого в казані і твоє завдання дійти до вершини гори, використовуючи скелястий молоток, і звучить це доволі легко, але незручне пересування ним робить це завдання майже неможливим: молоток може застрягнути в якихось об'єктах, часом малим дотиком до них молоток може тебе відштовхнути в бік на велику відстань, часом молоток може відстрибувати від них, і звучить це не так і погано якби в кожній секції гри не було ям, що можуть відкинути тебе на початок секції, або навіть на самий початок гри і що разу коли ти падаєш оповідач Беннет Фодді буде говорити свою філософію про втрату прогресу, біль, тощо. Це сильно демотивує грати цю гру і я теж хотів кинути її, але одна річ не давала мені цього зробити - це посил, що мені хоче дати гра. Коли ти втрачаєш свій прогрес Беннет каже тобі: Так, це фігово, але ти не повинен здаватись, просто вийди з гри і спробуй наступного дня. Це нормально застрягати на якомусь місці, до поки ти приділяєш час цій грі ти будеш бачити прогрес, за цей час ти зможеш зрозуміти фізику молотка і пройти далі, а підкорення кожної частини гори приносить задоволення, відчуття того що ти зробив неможливе для себе і найбільше це відчувається коли ти дійшов до вершини гори. 
Після гри в тебе буде ще вибір чи кинеш ти гру і будеш пишатись що ти її пройшов чи продовжиш грати аби зрозуміти краще керування, набути майстерності і стати тим хто зможе пройти гру за менше 10 хвилин, тим більше ти проводиш час в грі, тим більше майстерності ти набуваєш.
Getting Over It - це одна з хардкорних ігор, що найбільше відділяється від інших, вона не дає тобі програш за якісь момент, який ти не міг передбачити, це гра про досягнення мети та те що ніколи не треба здаватись. Ця гра - це витвір мистецтва.
Оцінка: 9.1/10

在众多独具特色的游戏中，《Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy》无疑是一款令人难以忘怀的作品。作为一名对这款游戏充满热情的玩家，我深感荣幸能够向大家分享我对它的喜爱以及强烈推荐的理由。
这款游戏以其独特的游戏机制和极具挑战性的玩法吸引了无数玩家的目光。它并非传统意义上的轻松娱乐游戏，而是需要玩家具备坚韧的毅力和耐心。在游戏中，玩家将控制一个身处缸中的角色，利用手中的锤子不断攀爬，克服各种艰难险阻。这种新颖的玩法让人在初次接触时就感到无比新奇，同时也激发了玩家们的挑战欲望。
《Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy》的魅力不仅仅在于其独特的玩法，还在于它所带来的深刻体验。每一次的攀爬都是一次对自己耐心和技巧的考验，每一次的失败都让人更加渴望成功。这种在挫折中不断前行的感觉，让玩家们在游戏中得到了成长和锻炼。它教会了我们在面对困难时不要轻易放弃，要坚持不懈地努力，相信自己最终能够克服一切障碍。
此外，这款游戏的画面风格虽然简约，但却蕴含着一种独特的艺术美感。游戏中的场景设计简洁而富有创意，给人一种清新脱俗的感觉。同时，游戏中的音乐也为玩家营造了一种紧张而又充满氛围感的游戏环境，进一步增强了玩家的沉浸感。
尽管这款游戏的难度颇高，可能会让一些玩家感到沮丧和挫败，但正是这种挑战性使得它更加具有吸引力。对于那些喜欢挑战自我、追求极致体验的玩家来说，《Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy》无疑是一款不可错过的佳作。
总的来说，《Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy》是一款具有独特魅力和深刻内涵的游戏。它以其新颖的玩法、富有挑战性的关卡、独特的艺术风格和深刻的游戏体验，赢得了众多玩家的喜爱。我衷心地向大家推荐这款游戏，希望更多的人能够体验到其中的乐趣和挑战，感受到在挫折中不断前行的力量。

Вот мои опыт и впечатления от прохождения этой игры: Представьте что вы купили игру вчера, дошли до определенных успехов но вышли в ярости и перезапустили ее сегодня. Чтобы как-то разукрасить обстановку вы решили впервые послушать Канье Веста, начиная с его первого альбома и с самого начала игры. Сначала вас всё бесит, вы застряли на одном этапе игры и не можете выбраться, тогда даже музыка кажется дурацкой а этот желтый оттенок уже надоел, прямо как и желтый цвет альбома. По мере продвижения идет следующий альбом, и я скажу так: он просто идеально подчёркивает каждый новый этап игры. Если быть точнее, я включил 2 альбом Канье после преодоления тех гор над апельсином и дела пошли в гору (может его песни мотивировали меня), далее я дошел до самой верхушки игры без единого падения, пока музыка подчёркивала все красоты уровня и мотивировала меня дальше. Я не помню когда в последний раз испытал такие эмоции, абсолютно благодарен создателю и Канье Весту. Absolute Cinema.
///
Here are my experiences and impressions of playing this game: Imagine that you bought the game yesterday, achieved some success, but came out furious and restarted it today. In order to somehow embellish the situation, you decided to listen to Kanye West for the first time, starting with his first album and from the very beginning of the game. At first, everything you off, you are stuck at one stage of the game and you can't get out, then even the music seems stupid and this yellow shade is already boring, just like the yellow color of the album. As it progresses, the next album is coming, and I'll say this: it just perfectly emphasizes each new stage of the game. To be more precise, I turned on Kanye's 2nd album after overcoming those mountains over the orange and things went uphill (maybe his songs motivated me), then I got to the very top of the game without a single drop, while the music emphasized all the beauty of the level and motivated me further. I don't remember the last time I experienced such emotions, I am absolutely grateful to the creator and Kanye West. Absolute Cinema.

P.S. Канье Вест - гений /// Kanye West is a genius.

184364969.review: There’s no feeling more intense than starting over. If you've deleted your homework the day before it was due, as I have, or if you left your wallet at home and you have to go back, after spending an hour in the commute, if you won some money at the casino and then put all your winnings on red, but it came up black, if you got your best shirt dry-cleaned before a wedding and then immediately dropped food on it, if you won an argument with a friend and then later discovered that they just returned to their original view, starting over is harder than starting up. If you're not ready for that, like if you've already had a bad day then what you're about to go through might be too much. Feel free to go away and come back. I'll be here. Alright, thanks for coming with me on this trip. I'll understand if you have to take a break at any point... Just find a safe place to stop, and quit the game. And don't worry, I'll save your progress, always. Even your mistakes. This game is a homage to a free game that came out in 2002, titled 'Sexy Hiking'. The author of the game was Jazzuo, a mysterious Czech designer who was known at the time as the father of B-games. B-games are rough assemblages of found objects. Designers slap them together very quickly and freely, and they're often too rough and unfriendly to gain much of a following. They built more for the joy of building them than as published products. In a certain way, Sexy Hiking is the perfect embodiment of a B-game. It's built almost entirely out of found and recycled parts, and it's one of the most unusual and unfriendly games of its time. In it, your task is simply to drag yourself up a mountain with a hammer. The act of climbing, in the digital world or real life, has certain essential properties that give the game its flavor. No amount of forward progress is guaranteed; some cliffs are too sheer or too slippery. And the player is constantly, unremittingly in danger of falling and losing everything. Anyway, when you start Sexy Hiking, you're standing next to a dead tree, which blocks the way to the entire rest of the game. It might take you an hour to get over that tree. A lot of people never got past it. You prod and poke at it, exploring the limits of your reach and strength, trying to find a way up. And there's a sense of truth in that lack of compromise. Most obstacles in video games are fake - you can be completely confident in your ability to get through them, once you have the correct method of the correct equipment, or just by spending enough time. In that sense, every pixellated obstacle in Sexy Hiking is real. The obstacles in Sexy Hiking are unyielding, and that makes the game uniquely frustrating. But I’m not sure Jazzuo intended to make a frustrating game - the frustration is just essential to the act of climbing and it’s authentic to the process of building a game about climbing. A funny thing that happened to me as I was building this mountain: I’d have an idea for an obstacle, and I’d build it, test it, and… it would usually turn out to be unreasonably hard. But I couldn’t bring myself to make it easier. It already felt like my inability to get past the new obstacle was my fault as a player, rather than as the builder. Imaginary mountains build themselves from our efforts to climb them, and it’s our repeated attempts to reach the summit that turns those mountains into something real. When you’re building a video game world you’re building with ideas. And that can be like working with quick-cement. You mold your ideas into a certain shape that can be played with and in the process of playing with them they begin to harden and set until they are immutable, like rock. At that point you can’t change the world - not without breaking it into pieces and starting fresh with new ideas. For years now people have been predicting that games would soon be made of prefabricated objects, bought in a store and assembled into a void. For the most part, that hasn’t happened, because the objects in the stores are trash. I don’t mean they look bad or they’re badly made, although a lot of them are. I mean they’re trash in the way that food becomes trash as soon as you put it in the sink. Things are made to be consumed in a certain context, and once the moment is gone they transform into garbage. In the context of technology those moments pass by in seconds. Overtime we've poured more and more refuse into this vast digital landfill we call the internet. It now vastly outnumbers and outweighs the things that are fresh and untainted and unused. When everything around us is cultural trash, trash becomes the new medium, the lingua franca of the digital age. You can build culture out of trash, but only trash culture. B-games, B-movies, B-music, B-philosophy. Maybe this is what this digital culture is. A monstrous mountain of trash, the ash-heap of creativity's fountain. A landfill with everything we ever thought of in it. Grand, infinite and unsorted. There's 3D models of breakfast, gen-xer's fanfic novels, scanned magazines, green-screen Shia LaBeouf, banned snuff scenes on liveleak, Facebook's got lifelike bots with unbranded adverts, and candid shots of Kanye, and Taylor swift mashups, car crash epic fail gifs, Russian dash cam vids, discussions of McRibs, discarded, forgotten, unrecycled, muddled, rotten, and untitled. Everything's fresh for about six seconds, until some newer thing beckons and we hit refresh. And there's years of persevering, disappearing into the pile, out of style, out of sight. In this context it's tempting to make friendly content, that's gentle, that lets you churn through it but not earn it. Why make something demanding, if it just gets piled up in the landfill. Filled with bland things? When games were new, they wanted a lot from you. Daunting you, taunting you, resetting and delaying you. Players played stoically. Now everyone's turned off by that, they want to burn through it quickly, a quick fix for the fickle, some tricks for the clicks of the feckless. But that's not your, you're an acrobat, you could swallow a baseball bat. Now I know most likely you're watching this on Youtube of Twitch while some dude with 10 million views does it for you, like a baby bird being fed chewed up food. That's culture too. But on the off-chance you're playing this, what I'm saying is Trash is disposable but maybe it doesn't have to be approachable. What's the feeling like? Are you stressed? I guess you don't hate it if you got this far Feeling frustrated it's underrated. An orange is sweet juicy fruit locked inside a bitter peel. That's not how I feel about a challenge. I only want the bitterness, its coffee, its grapefruit, its licorice. It feels like we're closer now, composer and climber, designer and user. You could have refused but you didn't. There was something in you that was hidden, that chose to continue. It means a lot to me that you've come this far, endured this much. Every wisecrack, every insensitivity, every setback you've forgiven me is a kingly gift you've given me. We have the same taste, you and I. It's not ambition. It's ambition's opposite. An obdurate mission to taste defeat. You'll feel bad if you win so I put this snake in for you. Have you ever thought about who you are in this. Are you the man in the pot, Diogenes? Are you his hand? Are you the top of his hammer? I think not- where your hand moves, the hammer may not follow, nor the man, nor the man's hand. In this you are his WILL. His intent. The embodied resolve in his uphill ascent. Now you've conquered the ice cliff, the platforms, the church and the rectory, the living room and the factory, the playground and the construction site, the granite rocks and the lakeside. You've learned to hike. There's no way left to go but up and in a moment I'll shut up, but let me say I'm glad you came. I dedicate this game to you, the one who came this far. I give it to you with all my love.

184315601.review:
Если вы ищете уникальный и вызывающий опыт в мире видеоигр, то **Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy** — это игра, которую стоит попробовать. Разработанная Беннетом Фодди, эта игра предлагает игрокам невероятно сложное и порой фрустрирующее приключение, которое тем не менее становится по-настоящему захватывающим.

**Почему стоит сыграть в Getting Over It?**

1. **Необычный геймплей**: В игре вы управляете персонажем, который находится в котле и использует молот, чтобы преодолевать препятствия. Управление требует точности и терпения, что делает каждое движение важным.

2. **Философские размышления**: Во время игры вы будете слышать комментарии разработчика, которые поднимают важные вопросы о терпении, упорстве и преодолении трудностей. Это добавляет глубину и смысл в процесс, заставляя задуматься о вашем собственном подходе к вызовам.

3. **Визуальный стиль**: Игра имеет уникальный художественный стиль, который сочетает в себе простоту и красоту. Каждый уровень представляет собой тщательно проработанный мир, который приятно исследовать.

4. **Чувство достижения**: Преодоление сложных участков и достижение новых высот в игре приносит невероятное удовлетворение. Каждый успех, даже самый маленький, становится настоящим триумфом.

5. **Сообщество и мемы**: Getting Over It стала культовой игрой, и её сложность породила множество мемов и обсуждений в интернете. Вы сможете поделиться своим опытом и посмеяться над общими трудностями с другими игроками.

6. **Идеально для стриминга**: Если вы любите смотреть игровые стримы, Getting Over It — это идеальная игра для этого. Наблюдать, как другие игроки борются с трудностями, может быть невероятно увлекательно и весело.

Если вы готовы к вызову и хотите испытать свои навыки, терпение и настойчивость, **Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy** — это игра, которая подарит вам уникальный опыт. Будьте готовы к фрустрации, но также и к огромному удовлетворению от преодоления препятствий. Попробуйте, и, возможно, вы откроете для себя новый уровень игрового опыта!

184108817.review:
Apesar da fama do jogo pela internet, Getting over it é um jogo incrivelmente satisfatório. 

No momento, eu concluí apenas uma escalada, sendo realizada em duas horas (este número pode variar muito dependendo do quanto você entende da física do jogo), planejo re jogar mais algumas vezes daqui um tempo. Apesar de ter o risco constante de falhar uma parte e ter que superar obstáculos antigos novamente, existem diversos pontos seguros para que a perca seja pequena, ou quase inexistente (a não ser que você pegue uma carona com a cobra engraçada), avançar no jogo é provar que você entendeu a movimentação e a física, no começo eu estava com um pouco de dificuldade, principalmente pela sensibilidade do jogo ser meio estranha, mas com o passar do tempo, tudo começou a fazer parte de mim, o final foi praticamente uma linha reta, foi bem gratificante.

No fim, eu recomendo Getting over it caso você esteja disposto a aprender e não se frustrar com alguns erros, também pode ser um ótimo jogo pra refletir pois a cada queda, Benneett Foddy faz o favor de compartilhar alguma frase filosófica ou motivacional.

184083288.review:
Genuinely, so freaking amazing, loved the game, loved the stupid music that began to play after you fell, and specially loved the deep meaning this game might have had inside. Giving up is an option sure, but if you don't yield and keep on going, maybe, someday, you'll achieve whatever you were looking for, and that feeling of getting to it is genuinely amazing.
Now speaking about the game-play itself, yeah, it's really... REALLY infuriating, it takes a lot of trial and error to get to the top, it does feel fluid tho, sometimes it does feel a bit janky, but nothing that makes it unbearable, it too does sometimes move kinda by itself, or changes speed without you actually changing anything, this one time I was in the snowman, moving REALLY slowly, and suddenly it just went really quick, which sent me flying, luckily didn't fall.
That's kind of it, the good overshadows the bad in this game, it does deserve all the support it got from all those YouTubers (and their fans) years ago, I'm glad I was able to play this game, I will definitely try getting that blue bow on my steam profile page by "getting over it" 49 more times lol. Thanks Bennett Foddy for suck an amazing yet simple game.

184029856.review: Firstly, the game is NOT perfect. Most rage-based games are absolutely terrible, having no sense of balance nor direction. However, this game is by far one of if not the best rage game out there today. Yes, I may have gotten incredibly mad at some spots of the game. However, I never felt it was the game's fault. Bennett Foddy's narrative can get somewhat annoying telling you some common nonsense after losing a heap of progress. Once you start to reach the end, Foddy congratulates you for getting so far. But the highlight of the game is the ending, more so the feeling. It's a feeling I did not feel after beating previous rage games, and for those reasons this game gets a edge over others. If your a person with an incredibly short fuse, I would not recommend this game. But for the players looking for a challenge, I would strongly recommend this game.

As an experience, this can be a great experience if you have the patience for it. 

As a game, Getting over it contains too many features with the sole purpose to frustrate and anger the player without much legitimately entertaining elements to make the repeat of the experience as you play through the game feel worth it. 183603443.review:
Uno dei rage game più riconoscibili degli anni 2010, con la fama di un sistema di controllo che è una vera e propria chiavica:  volutamente controintuitivo ed imprevedibile che farà ciò che volete metà delle volte, anche quando pensate di averlo masterato.

La forza nelle braccia di quest'uomo dentro la pentola deve essere impareggiabile, visto come maneggia quel martello e come scala la montagna di spazzatura ed elementi naturali che gli si para davanti. Il gioco è un alternarsi di bestemmie, false speranze, momenti di percepibile contentezza per un piccolo successo seguiti immediatamente dalla disperazione dopo che in un secondo si sono persi tutti i progressi. E di nuovo bestemmie.

Ammetto di aver litigato parecchio con il sistema di controllo e non ho intenzione di portare avanti ancora questa scalata, nonostante l'istinto di completismo e competitività mi stia dicendo di farlo. Ma non ho purtroppo molto tempo da dedicarvici. Quindi mi accontenterò di aver raggiunto (credo) il 40% della scalata e mi arrenderò qua. Magari un giorno lo riprenderò in mano.

183545431.review: There’s something uniquely captivating about Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy that keeps me coming back for more, no matter how frustrating it gets. I love the way the game challenges me not just physically with its precise controls but mentally, forcing me to face setbacks and learn from them. Every fall feels like a personal battle, but the thrill of progress—no matter how small—makes every climb feel meaningful. The minimalist design, combined with the soothing yet philosophical narration, creates an atmosphere that’s both punishing and oddly comforting.
